page.title: 10LOCAL HISTORY - BARKING
page.content: First mentioned in an Anglo Saxon Charter of 966, when and Ealdorman of Essex granted the parish to the Abbey of Ely. It remained as a food farm providing 2 weeks food a year for the Abbey until the time of Queen Elizabeth. The Crown sold it to Sir Francis Needham. It later passed to the Theobald family, then the Crowley family who were wealthy ironmasters, then by marriage it went to the Earls of Ashburnham in Sussex who held it 1920. The old manor house was rebuilt by the Ashburnhams and called Barking Hall. This was demolished in 1926 except for the stable block, which is used today, having been converted to a private house. Barking is noted for its ancient woodlands. The Church of St. Mary is in the early English style. One of its Rectors was Robert Uvedale the botanist.
